A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.
Does the concept of a/an Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Torsion element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a torsion element involves an element x of an A-module M and requires the existence of an element a in A (excluding 0) such that a.x = 0. This definition inherently relies on the structure of an A-module, which is a generalization of a vector space where the scalars come from a ring A instead of a field. The concept of a group, as defined, involves a set with an associative binary operation, a unit element, and inverses for every element. The definition of a torsion element does not require the elements of A or M to have inverses or a unit element, nor does it require the operation to be associative. Therefore, the concept of a group is not necessary to define a torsion element in an A-module. The essential structure needed is that of a ring (for A) and a module (for M), not a group.
